scenes.title: Three-front war for growth
scenes.main_point: AI raised expectations, broke distribution, and intensified competition.
scenes.scene_summary: AI raised customer expectations, collapsed channels, and put everyone after your value prop.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
A lone startup founder stands in a bustling marketplace where three crowds—incumbent executives, scrappy startups, and demanding customers—press in from different directions.
Above them, swirling AI-like glyphs and shifting signboards hint at collapsing distribution and rising expectations; the founder looks tense but determined.

scenes.title: A new playbook: Trust
scenes.main_point: Trust became the core concept behind the emerging growth model.
scenes.scene_summary: A new growth playbook emerged, and it centered on one concept: trust.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same war-room from scene 1, the same small startup team gathers around the table as the chaotic three-front battle map is replaced by a clean diagram labeled “TRUST” at the center.
They pause, focused and hopeful, as they begin sketching a new growth model radiating outward from trust.

scenes.title: Sponsor: Cello referral platform
scenes.main_point: Cello positioned referrals and affiliates as scalable, embedded growth.
scenes.scene_summary: Cello turned referrals and affiliates into embedded, automated, predictable product-led growth.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same cozy startup workspace as before, the same founder and small team gather around a desk as a friendly “Cello” referral platform dashboard appears on a laptop.
They connect referral and affiliate icons into the product flow, with automated attribution and reward badges lighting up, focused and hopeful.

scenes.title: Classic acquisition broke down
scenes.main_point: Traditional distribution got more expensive and less efficient.
scenes.scene_summary: Marketing channels got pricier and weaker, and they didn’t look like they’d recover soon.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
Same startup team from prior scenes stands around a whiteboard of funnel charts as the CAC line climbs and conversion bars shrink, looking worried.
In their cozy office, a wall poster reads “Andrew Chen” while a cracked “Distribution” pipeline diagram slumps downward.

scenes.title: SEO and search traffic eroded
scenes.main_point: AI content and AI answers reduced organic search value.
scenes.scene_summary: AI slop flooded SEO, and AI answers intercepted clicks before users reached websites.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
Same startup team from prior scenes stands in their office by a wall of growth charts as a wave of AI-generated blog pages floods a laptop screen.
A Google results page shows an AI answer box and nearby ChatGPT/Claude/Perplexity icons, while the team watches the organic traffic line sink, worried.

scenes.title: Paid search got squeezed
scenes.main_point: SEM economics worsened as competition rose and AI substitutes appeared.
scenes.scene_summary: SEM bids climbed on flat search volume, while $20 AI tools competed for the same jobs.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same small startup office, the same founder and teammate stare at a laptop showing a paid search dashboard as bid prices and CPC numbers climb while ROAS drops.
On the desk beside the laptop, a small “$20 AI tool” box sits next to a crowded list of competing keywords, both looking worried.

scenes.title: Corporate social lost leverage
scenes.main_point: Platforms deprioritized external links and punished corporate distribution.
scenes.scene_summary: Social algorithms favored on-platform engagement, and corporate links stopped converting into traffic.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same small startup office, the founder and marketer watch their corporate social post on a laptop as external link previews fade and engagement stays trapped on-platform.
A wall monitor shows volatile algorithm graphs and a growing queue of new creatives, conveying frustration at the interruption-marketing treadmill.

scenes.title: Trust-based acquisition channels
scenes.main_point: People, creators, community, and product experience transferred trust and drove word of mouth.
scenes.scene_summary: Employee voices, creators, communities, and product experience drove word of mouth through trust.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same startup office from earlier scenes, the core team shares authentic posts on a wall display while a friendly creator partner chats beside them.
Nearby, a small community circle gathers around a laptop showing the product experience, as word-of-mouth notes and referral arrows spread across a whiteboard, mood: hopeful trust.

scenes.title: AI weakened retention value props
scenes.main_point: Cheaper/faster value props got commoditized; trust became the differentiator.
scenes.scene_summary: AI beat many SaaS tools on cost and speed, so trust decided what users kept.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same cozy startup war-room, the small team watches a chalkboard of three value props (cheaper/efficient/effective) as a friendly AI spirit rapidly rewrites them into identical, generic notes.
Their faces show quiet worry as the “retention” column on the board fades, hinting commoditization and risk.

scenes.title: How trust-based retention got built
scenes.main_point: Roadmap transparency, fast feedback loops, WOW UX, thoughtful comms, and aligned monetization built confidence.
scenes.scene_summary: Teams built trust with real roadmaps, fast iteration, WOW moments, thoughtful comms, and outcome pricing.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same cozy startup office, the same small team gathers around a wall-sized transparent roadmap board covered with clear milestones and sticky-note feedback.
One teammate updates the roadmap while another refines a product screen showing a small “WOW” heart mark, and a third drafts a calm lifecycle message beside an outcome-based pricing chart, conveying steady confidence.

scenes.title: Trust unified acquisition and retention
scenes.main_point: Trust operated as one system across the journey, reinforced by personal examples.
scenes.scene_summary: Trust powered both acquisition and retention, and referrals plus continuous improvement made products dependable.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same cozy workshop office from earlier scenes, the founder stands beside a wall-sized “Trust System” board linking Acquisition → Referrals → Retention in one loop.
A small group of teammates adds sticky notes labeled “referrals,” “continuous improvement,” and a short list of trusted products, while the founder writes a personal trust statement; the mood is calm and confident.

scenes.title: Operational shift and closing warning
scenes.main_point: Org structure, velocity, and building in public created compounding trust as channels collapsed.
scenes.scene_summary: Teams broke silos, shipped fast, built in public, and shifted before channels collapsed completely.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Studio Ghibli anime style, soft pastel colors, hand-painted backgrounds, gentle lighting.
In the same startup war-room, the familiar cross-functional team stands together at a shared board labeled “Velocity” and “Micro-releases,” pinning public update notes while old channel charts fade behind them.
They look resolved yet cautious as a final note reads “Trust is the moat—shift before collapse.”
